sections.title: Replacing several missing teeth
sections.body:
When more than one tooth is missing, the choices become broader — and the planning becomes more important.

Multiple teeth can be replaced using individual implants, implants supporting a bridge, or implant-retained removable solutions. The right option depends on how many teeth are missing, where they are, and how your bite functions.
bullets: Implant-supported bridges that avoid drilling healthy neighbouring teeth
Secure chewing and speech thanks to steadier support
Phased plans that protect bone, gums, and bite balance

sections.title: Predictable stability for multi-tooth gaps
items: CBCT imaging and guided stents to position every implant for a balanced bridge
Close lab collaboration to shape bridgework that protects your bite and speech
Clear timelines with provisional options so you stay functional while healing

sections.title: Implant foundations that lock bridges in place
sections.body: Two or more titanium posts are carefully placed to anchor a bridge or partial denture, replacing several teeth with a stable, natural-feeling result that spreads chewing forces evenly.

sections.title: When multiple implants may be suitable
items: several teeth are missing in one area
existing dentures are unstable or uncomfortable
remaining teeth are heavily restored or failing
Suitability is always confirmed after assessment.

sections.title: Planning before placement
items: With multiple implants, we plan the teeth first, then the implants.
digital scans and imaging to assess bone and space
evaluating bite forces and chewing patterns
deciding whether teeth should be replaced individually or splinted
considering cleaning access and long-term maintenance
This planning stage reduces surprises and improves predictability.

sections.body: CBCT data, guided surgical sleeves, and torque-controlled placement keep each implant aligned, while lab partners craft bridgework that restores bite and speech.

sections.title: Common questions about replacing several teeth

faqs.question: How many implants do I need for multiple missing teeth?
faqs.answer: Many bridges use two or more implants to support several teeth; we plan the number based on bone quality, bite, and the length of the gap.

faqs.question: What is the timeline for multi-tooth implants?
faqs.answer: We share a clear schedule from planning and placement through healing to the final bridge, with provisional options if needed to keep you chewing.

faqs.question: Will I be without teeth during healing?
faqs.answer: We can often provide a temporary bridge or partial denture so you can smile and eat softer foods while the implants integrate.

faqs.question: Is it better than a traditional bridge?
faqs.answer: Implant-supported bridges avoid drilling healthy neighbouring teeth and give more stability for chewing, while helping maintain bone.

faqs.question: How do I clean around an implant-supported bridge?
faqs.answer: We demonstrate brushing and floss aids or interdental brushes to clean under the bridge and around the implant posts.

faqs.question: Does it hurt to place multiple implants?
faqs.answer: Placement uses local anaesthetic with gentle techniques; expect pressure and some soreness afterwards, managed with our aftercare plan.
